item.title: Extraterrestrial Civilizations (Book)
item.description:
Extraterrestrial Civilizations (Book) ðŸ”—

This entry details Isaac Asimov’s 1979 book, Extraterrestrial Civilizations, which explores the probability of intelligent extraterrestrial life within the Milky Way galaxy. The book approaches this estimation by systematically analyzing the requirements for life to exist.

Overview ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the core argument of Asimov’s book. A key concept is the “Earth-like world,” which assumes that habitable planets share similarities with Earth, such as suitable temperature ranges and sufficient gravity for an atmosphere. Asimov starts with an estimated 300 billion stars in the Milky Way. He then progressively reduces this number by considering factors like the presence of planetary systems. The analysis leads to an estimate of roughly 530,000 planets in our galaxy that could potentially harbor technological civilizations.

This section provides a link to the Drake equation, a probabilistic argument used to estimate the number of active, communicative extraterrestrial civilizations in the Milky Way galaxy.

This section lists the sources cited in the article. These include a review of Extraterrestrial Civilizations by J.H. Jenkins, archived on a personal website, and a listing for the book on The Internet Book Database of Fiction.
